sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• effect on cardiovascular morbidity and mortality has not been determined
  • safety and efficacy in Fredrickson Type I, III, IV, and V dyslipidemia not established
  • Familial hypercholesterolemia - homozygous: with atorvastatin or simvastatin, 10 mg ORALLY once daily
  • Mixed hyperlipidemia: in combination with fenofibrate, 10 mg ORALLY once daily
  • Primary hypercholesterolemia: alone or in combination with an HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor (statin), 10 mg ORALLY once daily
  • Sitosterolemia, Homozygous familial: 10 mg ORALLY once daily

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• safety and efficacy not established in children less than 10 years of age or in premenarchal girls
  • effect on cardiovascular morbidity and mortality has not been determined
  • safety and efficacy in Fredrickson Type I, III, IV, and V dyslipidemia not established
  • Familial hypercholesterolemia - homozygous: (12 years and older) with atorvastatin or simvastatin, 10 mg ORALLY once daily
  • Primary hypercholesterolemia: (10 years and older) alone or in combination with an HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor (statin), 10 mg ORALLY once daily
  • Sitosterolemia, Homozygous familial: (age 10 years and older) 10 mg ORALLY once daily

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• hepatic impairment, mild: no dosage adjustment required
  • hepatic impairment, moderate to severe: use not recommended
  • renal impairment: no dosage adjustment required
  • geriatric: no dosage adjustment required
  • concomitant simvastatin and moderate to severe renal impairment (estimated GFR less than 60 mL/min/1.73 m(2)): use caution and monitor closely with simvastatin doses exceeding 20 mg/day

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Familial hypercholesterolemia - homozygous
  • Mixed hyperlipidemia
  • Primary hypercholesterolemia
  • Sitosterolemia, Homozygous familial

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• concomitant use with a statin in pregnant or nursing mothers, patients with active liver disease, or unexplained persistent hepatic transaminase elevations
  • hypersensitivity to ezetimibe or any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• concomitant use with fibrates other than fenofibrate; use not recommended
  • concomitant use with simvastatin doses greater than 20 mg/day in moderate to severe renal impairment (estimated GFR less than 60 mL/min/1.73 m(2)); increased risk of myopathy; use caution and monitor closely
  • hepatic impairment, moderate to severe; use not recommended
  • myopathy including rhabdomyolysis may occur; increased risk with concomitant use of statin or fibrate; discontinue use is suspected or diagnosed
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (2.5% to 4.1%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (2.6% to 3%), Myalgia (3.2%)
  • Respiratory:Nasopharyngitis (3.7%), Sinusitis (2.8%), Upper respiratory infection (2.9% to 4.3%)
Serious
  • Hepatic:Hepatitis, Increased liver enzymes (0.5% to 3%)
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Musculoskeletal:Disorder of muscle, Rhabdomyolysis

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Ezetimibe reduces blood cholesterol by inhibiting absorption of cholesterol by the small intestine. Ezetimibe localizes and appears to act at the brush border of the small intestine and inhibits the absorption of cholesterol, leading to a decrease in the delivery of intestinal cholesterol to the liver. This causes a reduction of hepatic cholesterol stores and an increase in the clearance of cholesterol from the blood, this distinct mechanism is complementary to that of the HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors.

0.title: Absorption
0.mono: Systemic: Variable bioavailability; food effects none

2.title: Metabolism
2.mono: Systemic: Hepatic and small intestine; Metabolites: Ezetimibe-glucuronide, ezetimibe and ezetimibe-glucuronide

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • may be taken with or without food
  • may be administered at the same time a concurrent HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor (a statin) or fenofibrate is taken
  • take at least 2 hours before or 4 hours after administration of a bile acid sequestrant

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• lipid panel
  • serum creatine kinase in patients experiencing muscle pain and those receiving other drugs associated with myopathy

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
EZETIMIBE
OVERDOSE: Overdose data are limited. The signs and symptoms of an acute overdose are expected to be similar to excessive pharmacologic effects such as diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fatigue. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Ezetimibe is generally well tolerated by most patients. Back pain, arthralgia, diarrhea, abdominal pain, sinusitis, coughing, pharyngitis, fatigue, pancreatitis, and hepatotoxicity have been reported following ezetimibe therapy.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
EZETIMIBE
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Decontamination: Consider activated charcoal.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor fluid and electrolyte status in patients with significant diarrhea. Monitor hepatic enzymes in symptomatic patients.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: Hemodialysis is NOT expected to significantly enhance the clearance of ezetimibe due to extensive protein binding.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
EZETIMIBE
TOXICITY: Administration of ezetimibe to 16 patients, 50 mg/day for up to 14 days, was generally well tolerated. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: ADULT - The recommended dose is 10 mg orally once daily. PEDIATRIC - 10-18 years of age, the recommended dose is 10 mg orally once daily; not recommended for children less than 10 years of age.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause abdominal pain, diarrhea, back pain, headache, sinusitis, hepatitis, or angioedema (deep swelling around eyes and lips and sometimes hands and feet).
  • Advise patient to report arthralgias or myalgias.
  • Patient may take concomitantly with HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors ("statins").
  • Instruct patient to take at least 2 h before or 4 h after administration of a bile acid sequestrant (eg, cholestyramine).
